STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
July 2, 2021
Alisa Otto
Catholic Charities West Michigan - Muskegon
#125
1720 Park Street
Muskegon, MI 49441
RE: License #: CB610201023
Catholic Charities West Michigan - Muskegon
#125
1720 Park Street
Muskegon, MI 49441
Dear Ms. Otto:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
July 2, 2021. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract
and Modified Implementation Sustainability, and Exit Plan (MISEP) requirements, a
written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing
rules are also violations of the MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is
due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved; this includes identifying
behaviorally specific action steps.
o Repeat violations must include an explanation of why the previous
corrective action plan did not result in compliance.
 Individuals directly responsible for implementing the corrective action step for
each licensing statute and rule, Contract item, DHHS policy or MISEP section
citation, e.g. workers, supervisors, program managers, director, etc.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
implemented and completed.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved; this
includes identifying specific action steps for continuous monitoring.
o MiSACWIS users with access to the Book of Business, InfoView Reports
and the Monthly Child Welfare Management Report should incorporate the
use of these tools as well as other data management reports released by
the Department for continuous monitoring.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

 Signature of the responsible party and date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Jessica VandenHeuvel, the area manager at (616) 204-
6992.
Sincerely,
Paul Fatato, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
322 E. Stockbridge Ave
Kalamazoo, MI 49001
(269) 251-2471
enclosure
2

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12311 Foster parent/agency agreement.
(3) An agency shall document review of the foster
parent/agency agreement with the foster family at least
annually and, when needed, develop a new agreement.
Two of three active foster home files reviewed did not have the FPPA located in the
file. The signature page was present but not the agreement.
R 400.12312 Foster parent training.
(4) At least 1 adult member of the household shall have
training in and maintain a current certification in first aid
from the American Heart Association or the American Red
Cross or other institution approved by the department.
One of three active foster home files reviewed did not have documentation that
anyone in the home had training and certification in first aid or CPR.
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(2) The annual reevaluation shall include a determination
and assessment of all of the following:
(d) Compliance with the licensing rules for foster homes.
Two of three active foster home files reviewed did not have documentation that the
home was in compliance with licensing rules as required. This involved the first
home not practicing emergency procedures as required and the agency still finding
them in full compliance without the development of a CAP. The second home had an
Environmental Health Inspection due in May 2021, but this was not located in the
file.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by
another agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record
containing all of the following documents:
(d) A copy of the current reevaluation with written
endorsement by the borrowing agency that the evaluation
is acceptable.
4

Two of three active borrowed home files reviewed had no documentation that the
recent reevaluation was endorsed.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(1) An agency shall do all of the following when anyone in
the agency receives information that relates to possible
noncompliance with any foster home rule:
(a) Submit a special investigation record to the
department's licensing authority within 5 working days in
the manner prescribed by the department.
One of two special evaluations reviewed did not have documentation that the record
was submitted to the department within 5 working days.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(1) An agency shall do all of the following when anyone in
the agency receives information that relates to possible
noncompliance with any foster home rule:
(c) Conduct a thorough investigation including all
necessary collateral contacts.
Two of two special evaluations reviewed did not have documentation that all
individuals involved were interviewed thoroughly as required.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(3) An agency shall complete a special evaluation within 45
calendar days after receipt of the information. If additional
time is required, then the agency shall inform the foster
parent, in writing, of the basis for the extension and the
expected length of the extension. The total time for the
completion of the investigation shall not exceed 90
calendar days without written approval from the chief
administrator or his or her designee.
One of two special evaluations reviewed did not have documentation that the
expected length of the extension was provided as required.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all of
the following information:
(a) The date the information was received.
5

One of two special evaluations reviewed did not have documentation that the report
was completed within the required 15-days. The last interview took place on 5/6/21
and the report was not completed until 6/14/21.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all of
the following information:
(f) Conclusions regarding licensing rules compliance or
noncompliance based on the findings of fact.
One of two special evaluations reviewed did not include enough details and
verification of information to make a conclusion based on findings of facts.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance will all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note that there
are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements except
for the following:
6

722-08E P. 1 FOSTER CARE/JUVENILE JUSTICE ACTION SUMMARY
The DHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary
is used to document specific administrative actions or
changes in a case, including: • Child fatality. • Change in
caseworker or organization. • Change in parent contact
information. • Foster care transfer to adoption. • Change in
placement. • Temporary break from placement. • Program
or case closing.
COMPLETION REQUIREMENTS The caseworker must
complete the DHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action
Summary and upload to MiSACWIS within the timeframe
required for the specified action/change.
Placement Change - Prior to a planned placement change,
or within three business days of an emergency placement
change.
One of six active foster care case files reviewed did not have the required DHHS-69
completed for a replacement of the youth.
FOM 801-03 Medical Passport
All medical information within the medical passport must
be current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the
child's current and complete health information.
Two of six active foster care case files reviewed did not have documentation that the
Medical Passport was completed as required. This involved one case with the
Medical Passport not being completed quarterly and the second case with the
agency not ensuring that the Medical Passport was present when receiving the case
from another agency.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim Report dated 7/14/20, CAP approval date 8/3/20.
Renewal Report dated 6/19/19, CAP approval date 6/26/19.
Interim Report dated 7/18/18, CAP approval date 8/3/18.
FOM 722-08 Supervisory Approval Initial Service Plan
Case service plan approval process requires the foster care
supervisor to:
Review and approve the ISP within 14 calendar days of the
Report Date.
7

One of six active foster care case files reviewed did not have the supervisor’s
approval on the Initial Service Plan within the required 14-days. The supervisor
approved the report 1 day late.
FOM 722-08C Required Participation in Development -
Completion of the parent-agency treatment plan (PATP) and
service agreement requires the foster care worker to
engage in a discussion with the parent/guardian on case
planning. Parental participation is required in developing
the parent/caretaker goals and objectives.
Youths age 14 and older must participate in developing the
individual activities regarding their own service plan; see
FOM 722-06, Independent Living Preparation.
The foster parent/caregiver must be included in the PATP
process. The foster parent/caregiver signature is required
and indicates that the foster parent/caregiver
acknowledges and agrees to the activities required to meet
the needs of the child in their care.
Five of six active foster care case files reviewed did not have documentation that the
required participation (signatures) in the development met the requirements. This
involved eight Parent Agency Treatment Plans with four missing parental signatures,
three missing youth signatures, one missing caregiver signature, and two late
caregiver signatures.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim Report dated 7/14/20, CAP approval date 8/3/20.
Renewal Report dated 6/19/19, CAP approval date 6/26/19.
Interim Report dated 7/18/18, CAP approval date 8/3/18.
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meetings
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as out-
lined in the following tables:
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment- Updated Case
Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before the case plan
due date.
Placement Preservation/ Disruption- At least three business
days prior to a planned change of placement or no later
than three business days after an unplanned placement
change.
8

Three of six active foster care case files reviewed did not have documentation that
the FTM was completed as required. This involved one missing FTM for a USP, two
FTMs taking place outside of the 30-day requirement for USPs, and one FTM taking
place outside of the required time frame for a replacement.
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meetings- FTM Practice guidance
The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report, is used to
capture family demographics, FTM logistical information,
needs, strengths, action steps, safety concerns and the
safety plan, and any recommendations made for the family
during the FTM. The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be
completed for every FTM.
Two of six active foster care case files reviewed did not have the required
documentation for a FTM present in the file. This involved three missing DHHS-1105
for three FTMs.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim Report dated 7/14/20, CAP approval date 8/3/20.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
Several items were coded with different names and the agency appears to struggle
with consistency when coding items. This was discussed at the exit meeting.
There were five signatures on PATPs with no date provided. This was discussed with
the agency at the exit meeting.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
The development of a compliance department or individual was discussed to help
the agency ensure an increase in their rate of compliance.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
AND
9

The agency submitted one acceptable corrective action plan during this period under
review. This action place was in regards to the 2020 Licensing interim inspection.
Interviews were completed with staff during this inspection and all staff reported
feeling supported by the agency, especially with the COVID-19 changes that have
taken place. They report this is a positive place to work and the supervisors have an
open-door policy. Administration staff interviewed present with a strong desire to
provide “best practice” to their families and youth. All staff report strong
communication between upper management and their direct supervisor. They also
report the agency provides opportunities for training and growth.
VII. DCWL FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no safety alerts or concerns during this review.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will
be issued a renewal of their regular license.
7/2/2021
________________________________________
Paul Fatato Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
July 2, 2021
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
10
